Continuing $Y' = AY$

We are guessing $Y = f(t)u \implies f'(t)u = f(t)Au$
$Au \parallel u \iff u$ is an eigenvector of $A$
$Au = \lambda u \iff \lambda$ is an eigenvalue of $A$
$\lambda = \frac{f'(t)}{f(t)} \iff f(t) = e^{\lambda t} u$

We have $Y(t) = c_1e^{\lambda_1 t}u_1 + c_2e^{\lambda_2 t}u_2$
$Y(0) = Y_0 = c_1u_1 + c_2u_2$; does this satisfy arbitary $Y_0$?

Solvable $\forall Y_0 \iff \matrixstart u_1 & u_2 \matrixend \matrixstart c_1 \\ c_2 \matrixend = Y_0 \iff \matrixstart u_1 & u_2 \matrixend$ is invertible $\iff \det \matrixstart u_1 & u_2 \matrixend \neq 0$

Define $S := \matrixstart u_1 & u_2 \matrixend$

Then $\matrixstart c_1 \\ c_2 \matrixend = S^{-1}Y_0$

Further, $Y(t) = S \matrixstart c_1e^{\lambda_1t} \\ c_2e^{\lambda_2t} \matrixend = S \matrixstart e^{\lambda_1t} & 0 \\ 0 & e^{\lambda_2t} \matrixend \matrixstart c_1 \\ c_2 \matrixend = S \matrixstart e^{\lambda_1t} & 0 \\ 0 & e^{\lambda_2t} \matrixend S^{-1} Y_0$

We let $\Psi(t) = S \matrixstart e^{\lambda_1t} & 0 \\ 0 & e^{\lambda_2t} \matrixend S^{-1}$ and write $Y(t) = \Psi(t)Y_0$. $\Psi$ typically takes a form $e^{At}$.

Sketching is a coordinate mapping. Cf. wksht #$20$

Complex:

$\lambda = a \pm bi$
$\bar u = u \pm iv$
$Y_\Re = e^{at}(u\cos(bt) - v\sin(bt))$
$Y_\Im = e^{at}(u\sin(bt) + v\cos(bt))$

$Y = c_1Y_\Re + c_2Y_\Im$

$S := \matrixstart u & v \matrixend$

$Y(t) = e^{at} S \matrixstart \cos(bt) & \sin(bt) \\ -\sin(bt) & \cos(bt) \matrixend S^{-1}Y_0$

Could this be a rotation by angle $\theta = bt$?!
